So whatever you say
is like the end.

2657.65.text:
>> Hi. Thank you guys
for giving a talk today.

2661.42.text:
I'm a writer and I'm
working on a project

2664.23.text:
at the moment that
is memoristic.

2666.30.text:
And it starts like quite
a lot of your memoirs,

2673.52.text:
And I was wondering how you
sort of pushed through to write

2681.13.text:
about those like memories
that are quite painful?

2684.69.text: And for lack of a better word,

2686.10.text:
what self-therapy did you
use to get through that?

2690.28.text:
>> I didn't really think
of it as therapeutic.

2697.19.text:
and with a strong focus on
narrative and suspense and arc.

2705.73.text:
And I knew those stories
that I wanted to tell

2710.11.text:
that would serve
those larger themes.

2712.83.text:
And I actually found
that the parts

2716.63.text:
that as a reader
potentially might come

2719.82.text:
across as the most vulnerable,
often you're focussing on syntax

2725.36.text:
and you're focussing on the
tempo of that paragraph.

2731.10.text:
Yeah, I guess to me
it was so different

2735.60.text:
from like writing a
diary or something.

2737.24.text:
That feels therapeutic, or
sitting in an analyst's office

2742.11.text:
But the process of writing
about painful experiences,

2745.37.text:
to me the pain is just getting
up in the morning and writing

2748.59.text: and having it be a good sentence

2750.43.text:
or a good paragraph
or a good book.

2752.18.text: That to me is much harder.

2754.01.text:
Only in retrospect I think,
when I was doing the audiobook,

2758.58.text:
then I was sort of
approaching it

2761.50.text:
with a little bit
more objectivity.

2764.53.text:
It had maybe moments
that were therapeutic.

2767.09.text:
But certainly I did
not approach --

2770.16.text:
I think there's just too much
construction involved really.

2773.97.text: Maybe a first draught, I guess.

2777.03.text:
I think a draught
is where you get

2781.81.text:
And then you just get in there
with an axe and you write.

2789.68.text:
You've got those closest to you
whose stories are being told.

2793.81.text:
>> You know, I found that
people are more offended

2805.07.text:
>> So everyone should be
grateful who was included.

2806.63.text:
I think we have one
more question possible,

2808.85.text:
or maybe a couple more
over her at mic one.

2815.61.text:
>> I know that it's a fatiguing
question, being a woman in rock.

2821.44.text:
But I suppose I wanted
to ask about --

2824.46.text:
we were talking about scenes
and being involved in them,

2826.78.text:
how specific they can be,
and I wondered how much --

2830.70.text:
I mean you're in
all-female band.

2833.08.text:
And how much of that is being
in conversation with other women

2837.72.text:
with specific to the art
that you're producing.

2840.49.text:
And from the memoir
it seems that a lot

2842.82.text:
of the people you were getting
inspiration from were women.

2845.75.text:
Do you think that
there was that divide

2848.00.text:
that you weren't being inspired
by the men in that scene?

2850.67.text:
Or was it you just
weren't in contact

2855.49.text:
Or was there a specific
conversation

2860.25.text:
>> Definitely influence-wise,
I don't think it kind

2864.83.text: of split down a gender line.

2868.92.text:
You know, my favourite
guitarists are

2875.90.text:
I guess in terms of inspiration,
yeah it's a little more fluid.

2881.97.text:
And the tricky thing about
asking what it's like to sort

2888.23.text: of play with Janet and Corin is

2890.27.text:
that I don't really have another
experience to compare it to.

2894.73.text:
So it's hard to kind
of step outside

2897.82.text:
of how we operate
and compare it.

2903.01.text:
You know, I do think that
-- I mean I really --

2908.96.text:
like Janet is just one
of the best drummers.

2911.59.text:
And the fact that she -- you
know I do I guess like playing

2916.66.text:
with people, and women often
fall into this category,

2920.75.text:
of someone who's going
to be underestimated.

2923.75.text:
Because then you have
something to prove.

2925.80.text:
And when you get onstage with
someone or you work with someone

2928.57.text:
that you think, "Everyone
out there is just going

2930.47.text:
to think this person can't
do it," then you're going

2934.48.text:
to damage someone
when you do it.

2935.99.text:
Because you're going
to surprise them.

2938.00.text:
And I think surprise, even
though you have to create --

2941.48.text:
like that's why I think
people are really drawn

2944.67.text:
to any narrative that
comes from a place

2949.13.text:
Because then you're clawing
and you're scratching.

2951.14.text: And that can come from anyone.

2953.05.text:
But I think for some people, you
know, that's harder to create.

2955.92.text:
If you just come from
a place where you were

2957.85.text:
with the assumption, like
"I'm going to be president

2961.08.text:
because I've only
ever seen these kind

2963.46.text:
Or "I've only ever seen these
kind of people play guitar."

2965.98.text:
There's a certain
kind of entitlement

2967.72.text:
that I think you can still
obviously be a brilliant artist

2972.07.text:
and come from a place
of entitlement.

2974.04.text:
But I personally I
think am drawn to people

2977.05.text:
that have operated
in the margins

2979.17.text:
and have pulled the
centre over to the margins.

2982.69.text:
Instead of people that
have started at the margins

2986.71.text:
And you know, Janet and Corin,
for a variety of reasons,

2990.70.text:
perhaps including their
gender, both encompass that.

2993.66.text:
And across the board
I'm drawn to artists

2996.54.text:
with that you know,
point of view.

3002.26.text:
>> Mic two, over
here in the corner.

3005.72.text:
>> This is so lame, but I
was sort of like daydreaming

3009.56.text:
about this when I saw
you and Miranda before.

3012.32.text:
So I guess I was
wondering what you guys do

3025.08.text:
I thought you were going to
go see that other person.

3038.44.text:
>> Maybe Miranda
should come to the mic.

3040.67.text:
Last time we hung out I
think was on your birthday.

3045.54.text:
I actually -- you
can ask Miranda,

3048.02.text:
this is not a lie,
I'm very antisocial.

3054.05.text:
I mean I love like
one-on-one interactions

3055.77.text:
and small group interactions,
but I wanted

3058.28.text:
to have this housewarming
dance party so we can put

3062.29.text: on our outfits like friends do.

3066.19.text:
She texted me a picture
of her outfit.

3068.84.text:
I said, "Yes, I'm going
to wear a dress too."

3083.02.text:
And this is why she's
basically --

3086.75.text:
one reason you have
a best friend is

3089.36.text:
so they come really
to the party.

3091.76.text: And so she kind of helped

3093.90.text:
like broker the other
early people who came.

3098.09.text:
Miranda was there to help
usher them in and get them ice

3101.80.text:
so I didn't have
to talk to them.

3103.63.text:
Because you know how people come
to your party and you're like,

3110.35.text:
So yeah, we don't like
do drawing or hiking.

3118.06.text:
We don't like just paint
each other's bodies

3127.77.text:
Oh yeah, we have
someone else at mic two.

3131.10.text:
>> I just wanted to ask, in
your book you're very open

3135.02.text:
about the physical and emotional
toll that touring had on you.

3138.79.text:
This time around you've been
touring with [inaudible],

3140.57.text: you've been doing a book tour.

3142.50.text:
You've been filming
Portlandia and Transparent.

3144.96.text:
This seems like a very personal
question, but how are you?

3153.18.text:
It only took 55 minutes for
someone to ask how I was.

3159.74.text:
I feel it's honestly
the happiest I've been.

3165.41.text:
It was such a rewarding
year last year.

3168.75.text:
And I feel like I
just surround myself

3176.85.text:
The endeavours with
which I'm involved,

3181.27.text:
there are wonderful
people I work with.

3184.57.text: And fans of the band and show.

3201.05.text:
>> I'm sorry I didn't
ask earlier.

3203.07.text:
>> You can see Sleater-Kinney
tonight at the opera house.

3206.38.text:
I'm very excited that
they have returned

3207.84.text:
after about 10 years away since
their last Australian tour.

3211.62.text:
Janet is one of the
world's best drummers.

3215.13.text:
It's incredible to
watch live onstage.

3218.22.text:
Carrie has also signed a
number of her brilliant memoirs

3224.78.text:
If you are quick I'm
sure that you can buy one

3226.77.text:
that has been signed, Hunger
Makes Me A Modern Girl.

3229.24.text:
And yeah, Portlandia of
course is continuing.

3232.68.text:
There will be another
season as well.

3234.62.text:
>> So you're going to
continue making things,

3238.55.text:
And thank you so much
for giving us your time

3241.21.text:
and sharing your
life with us today.
